Our correspondents Of the Boston Statesman, have
forwarded us extracts from the Gibraltar Chronicle
OF the Sd and 9Th of Nov. received at that port on
Saturday. The following account of an action be-
tween the Algerne and French squadrons. was re-
ceived at Gibraltar in letter from Agicrs


The Aisernes had been for some time preparing,
for the avowed object ofa'tackng the French force
and the night of Oct. Sd. between the of Ma
honet's nativity their squadron consisting of the
following ships put to sea frigate of so guns
corvette Che admIral's ship SO guns another
yette "a guns; another so guns two three-masted
schooners, l6 guns each two ,chooners, l6 do. do
two do. l2 do. do. two do. 10 do. do. and brig
of 1 guns.


Early the following morning they were seen
steering to the N. w. whilst the French squadron
consisting of so gun (the admral's ship an
other of the same class and meta.-2 briggs, one Of
20 aud the other of 1 guns appeared at consider
able distance in the oiling. bearing down with
norherly wind upon the enemy. On their approach
to each other both squadrons man@uyered for some
time to get the weather gage.-At O'Clock, p. NJ.
the ac ctiun commenced, and was continued courage
ousIy on both sides for two hours and quarter
The intention of the Algerines evidently appeared
to be to board, rather than to fight at distance
but their object was frustrated by the windward po-
sition of the French ships The French Admiral
bore the brunt OF the action. and for some time sus-
tanned the united attacks Of the Algerne Admra's
ship, two coryettes and a schooner. Al quarter

Letter from Washington published in the New
York Commercial, says. In addition TO the let
ters Of Mr. Clay to DR.. Goldman and Gen. MI lure,
am informed that our beloved Lafayette has in
terposed to vindcate the reputation Of distinguish
ed statesman from foul and deliberate calumuv.
Clay, it appears, asowed to the Nation, Guest,
at an early day, his determination of voting for MIR.
Adams, and for the satisfaction of the American
people. to whom the fame Of her patriotic sons is
dear. hope the person, to whom this attestation
of Mr.. Ciay's innocence was communicated, will be
induced to allow its publication.

is again candidate as an Eector of President u.

lie IS on the side of the Administration. and if we
mistake not, was chosen as an Elector in 1924.

Considerations upon the increase OF population
and industry of the United States OF Aneuca. We
have already remarked IN several articles, the
tonishing progress of agriculture, industry, COM
merce and the arts, in the various states u the un-
ion. Born but yesterday, and already covered w,th
an active population, thus immense population VIII
shortly see nothing to envy or desire in the old on
tinen III fast sailing ships have long been lccus-
toned to every sea. Her produt tons, .nch CON
sst chiefly OF articles Of the first necessity, nourl.h
the new as well as the old word. Her machlneries
OF every sort IN operation IN all quarters, and IN
crease in the products of the soil. Another in which
we tattered ourselves that we should be unr,valed
that olprntng and engraving has long been naturali-
zed there, and her daily and weekly newspapers, as
we have already observed, surpass IN number and
SIZE those Of all Europe, with the exception Of En-
gland. The heavy .Hoaiteu itself wouhi tppear q
Gothic, unsubstaniia thlng when compared with

After having wisely begun upon articles Of lmne-
dlata necessity, III manufacturing to an extent be-
yoni their direct wants, the common sorts of cloth
tlc americans win an inuefdliSdDt SplFll, nave SCI
up new manufacturers of more choice articles they
already raise and manufacture silk Emigration
carries them constant acquisition OF artists IN eve
ry new description OF industry whom they lmmedi
atcly put in practice. The vine has ceased TO be
cultivation for mere show and rarity 1t is raised II
large qualities IN some parts where we are assur
ed excellent wine mas been manufactured
The soil OF this country is more fertile, less eX
haisted and enjoys greater variety of climate thai
our own. Why should it not furnish them with eve
ry production OF our country Thore is no doubt
it will A country SO i;youred by nature, lntersect
ed in every part by immense rivers and seas o!fresl
water, whose canals roads, and facilities for trans
portation multiply necessarily where tna population
is not as in Europe, an aiTlir of calculations, but
natural want it is impossible to satisfy in too great
degree, where the government exrrts ieeiito pro
mote and foster every thing Of public utitity, wher
the industry of man reaps the whAe fruit of its OK
ertion, where the boy ofsixteen may be independent
where commerce finds out in her ports and j
the most renue corners of the earth, new channels


where the soil affords supply of coal, iron, leat


copper, and the most valuable metals the nhab


tants must soon look upon lis with pity, and brn
about fatal revolution in our trade, by becoming
, in many points OF view, a country Of production
instead of country OF consumption.


What will become of the manufactures at Pari


Lyon, Roucn, &c. of which \merca has hither
: been the principal consumer? In ten years, at tt
! farhest, we shall be enabled to answer this que


ton.

Considerations upon the increase OF population
and industry of the United States OF Aneuca. We
have already remarked IN several articles, the
tonishing progress of agriculture, industry, COM
merce and the arts, in the various states u the un-
ion. Born but yesterday, and already covered w,th
an active population, thus immense population VIII
shortly see nothing to envy or desire in the old on
tinen III fast sailing ships have long been lccus-
toned to every sea. Her produt tons, .nch CON
sst chiefly OF articles Of the first necessity, nourl.h
the new as well as the old word. Her machlneries
OF every sort IN operation IN all quarters, and IN
crease in the products of the soil. Another in which
we tattered ourselves that we should be unr,valed
that olprntng and engraving has long been naturali-
zed there, and her daily and weekly newspapers, as
we have already observed, surpass IN number and
SIZE those Of all Europe, with the exception Of En-
gland. The heavy .Hoaiteu itself wouhi tppear q
Gothic, unsubstaniia thlng when compared with

After having wisely begun upon articles Of lmne-
dlata necessity, III manufacturing to an extent be-
yoni their direct wants, the common sorts of cloth
tlc americans win an inuefdliSdDt SplFll, nave SCI
up new manufacturers of more choice articles they
already raise and manufacture silk Emigration
carries them constant acquisition OF artists IN eve
ry new description OF industry whom they lmmedi
atcly put in practice. The vine has ceased TO be
cultivation for mere show and rarity 1t is raised II
large qualities IN some parts where we are assur
ed excellent wine mas been manufactured
The soil OF this country is more fertile, less eX
haisted and enjoys greater variety of climate thai
our own. Why should it not furnish them with eve
ry production OF our country Thore is no doubt
it will A country SO i;youred by nature, lntersect
ed in every part by immense rivers and seas o!fresl
water, whose canals roads, and facilities for trans
portation multiply necessarily where tna population
is not as in Europe, an aiTlir of calculations, but
natural want it is impossible to satisfy in too great
degree, where the government exrrts ieeiito pro
mote and foster every thing Of public utitity, wher
the industry of man reaps the whAe fruit of its OK
ertion, where the boy ofsixteen may be independent
where commerce finds out in her ports and j
the most renue corners of the earth, new channels


where the soil affords supply of coal, iron, leat


copper, and the most valuable metals the nhab


tants must soon look upon lis with pity, and brn
about fatal revolution in our trade, by becoming
, in many points OF view, a country Of production
instead of country OF consumption.


What will become of the manufactures at Pari


Lyon, Roucn, &c. of which \merca has hither
: been the principal consumer? In ten years, at tt
! farhest, we shall be enabled to answer this que


ton.
